7.text:
Just before I start, I was giving a lecture
in Sheffield on Sunday and I was talking about

12.text:
the evacuees. And so much in the press about
particularly children in the Second World

18.text:
War is grim and gruesome because bad stories
make good press. And I decided to counter

24.text:
with some good news stories about children
in the Second World War. And a chap came up

28.text:
to me afterwards and he said, ‘Listening
to you is like listening to Enid Blyton talking

31.text:
about the Second World War,’ which was pretty
hurtful - I was quite taken aback by it.

36.text:
But what I do want to say about the lecture
today is I’m speaking about my grandfather.

41.text:
He was the colonel, Colonel Toosey, who was
depicted by Alec Guinness in the film 'Bridge

46.text:
on the River Kwai'. And when he spoke about
his experiences in Thailand he said, ‘Never

52.text:
let anybody tell you that it was always grim
all the time. There were moments when I was

58.text:
frightened, there were moments when I was
in severe danger, but there were also moments

62.text:
when I learnt more about the spirit of human
beings.’

65.text:
So, if I do emphasise the positive, it’s
because I’m his granddaughter.

71.text:
Is there anybody in this room who has not
seen the film 'The Bridge on the River Kwai'?

75.text:
There is a lady in the background. Well, will
you allow me to tell the story as I go along,

83.text:
and if you find any holes in the story, let
me know.

86.text:
The film was released in 1957, it won seven
Oscars in the 1958 ceremonies. It became for

93.text:
many the most... or one of the most famous
war films of all time.

99.text:
It was based on a book by a Frenchman called
Pierre Boulle. Now, Pierre Boulle was an interesting

104.text:
character. He wrote the book in 1952, so just
seven years after the war. He had been a French

110.text:
engineer, trained in Avignon. He went out
to Malaya as a rubber planter in 1935, and

118.text:
he was in Malaya working in the rubber plantations
when the Japanese invasion happened.

124.text:
He had trained as a saboteur, and of course
part of the film is the story of the destruction

130.text:
or the planned destruction of the bridge,
as well as Colonel Nicholson’s construction

135.text:
of the bridge. And that is where Boulle got
a lot of his sources from.

139.text:
He was also imprisoned, not by the Japanese,
but in fact by the Vichy French, and he spent

145.text:
three and a half years in Hanoi. So, he had
a great deal of first-hand experience, although

150.text:
he himself had not been on the Thailand-Burma
railway. So, the novel is based on stories

156.text:
that he had from the rubber planters who were on the 
railway and from his own experiences in the war.

162.text:
And when he came to talk about the book in
later life, he was very keen to emphasise

167.text:
that the film was very much an amalgamation
of his fiction and a screenplay written for

175.text:
Alexander Korda Films in 1955 at the instigation
of Sam Spiegel - so, it was a real conflagration

183.text:
of stories from the railway, so the whole
film is at least two steps away from the reality.

191.text:
And this is a picture of Pierre Boulle in
later life. He never really settled after

195.text:
the war. He went back to live in Paris in
a hotel, and after he’d written 'Bridge

198.text:
on the River Kwai' he also wrote 'La Planète
des Singes', or 'Planet of the Apes'.

205.text:
So the film is centred around these two characters.
In the centre, Alec Guinness playing the role

212.text:
of Colonel Nicholson, the bone-headed intransigent
British Army colonel who ends up by building

219.text:
a bridge for the Japanese. And on the right,
played by Sessue Hayakawa, Colonel Saito who

226.text:
is the Japanese officer put in charge of the
camp, and his job is to get the bridge built

232.text: with as much speed as possible.

235.text:
Now the real-life colonel was not a full-time
army colonel, he was in the Territorial Army.

241.text:
This is a photograph of him taken in 1935
when he was on a civilian trip to Brazil.

247.text:
He was in fact a merchant banker from Liverpool
and his interest in the Army only really grew

253.text:
as the thunderclouds of war drew closer and
darker during the 1930s.

259.text:
He joined the territorial army in 1929, not
really out of passion, to be honest, but out

264.text:
of the instruction of the commanding officer
of his Territorial Army unit, seated third

271.text:
from the right, Colonel Alan Todd, who also
happened to be his boss at Barings Bank.

276.text:
And what... and you didn’t say no to Alan
Todd. He was behind the... he was the man

281.text:
that was responsible for a lot of the financing
in Liverpool cathedral. But Toosey is on your

285.text:
left sitting down, on the screen. And what
is interesting is that the two majors that

291.text:
they were at the outbreak of war on the left,
and the two on the right, all four of them

294.text:
became honorary brigadiers by the end of the
war, so it was a regiment of some distinction.

300.text:
They went out to France at the beginning of
the war and he was involved, Toosey and his

306.text:
regiment were involved in the retreat from
Dunkirk. And this is a photograph, a very

311.text:
familiar photograph I’m sure to all of you,
of the... getting rid of the 358-odd thousand

318.text:
soldiers and civilians who were captured or
were going to be threatened to be captured

323.text:
He came into Margate hugely humiliated by
the experience. In fact he said later to his

329.text:
biographer, ‘If anybody asks me what I did
in the Second World War, tell them I ran like hell,

335.text:
twice, and the second time we ran out
of land.’ Now that silly comment actually

339.text:
covered quite a severe humiliation, because
he really only had about two and a half, three

344.text:
weeks of fighting in France, and he was determined
that he wasn’t going to spend the entire

350.text: war simply being a grown-up home guard.

353.text:
So he asked to be sent to Officer Training
School, which he was. And in the autumn of

359.text:
1941 he was sent from Gourock to Nova Scotia
with a regiment, an East Anglian regiment,

366.text:
that was the 135 Herts Yeomanry, a medium
gunner regiment. And he was sent over there

371.text:
where he was then transshipped and he was
going to be going to the Middle East. And

376.text:
he said, ‘How did we know? Well, our destination
was secret, but our guns and our boxes were

385.text:
So this is the photograph of the Mount Vernon
which is the ship that they went out on. And

391.text:
on the morning of 8 December 1941 he was in
the captain’s cabin when he heard the devastating

399.text:
news of the strikes on Pearl Harbour. Two
days later the captain reported the loss of

405.text:
the 'Prince of Wales' and the 'Repulse' off
Singapore, and immediately his regiment and

410.text:
the other troops in the 18th Division were
told that they would not be going to the Middle

415.text: East, they would be going out to Singapore.

417.text:
Toosey landed on Singapore on 27 January 1942.
He landed and he went straight up to the mainland

425.text:
and he fought at Johor Bahru and then he came
down onto the island along with the retreat

431.text:
with the Australians and the Indian regiments
that were regrouping on the island. He had

436.text:
about ten days fighting and then he was up
at Nee Soon, by the reservoir, and he was

443.text:
ordered on 13 February to go into General
Key’s office – General Key was in charge

447.text:
of the Indian Division of which he was seconded
to – and he was told two days before the

453.text: surrender that he was to be evacuated to India.

457.text:
And he turned round to General Key and he
said, ‘No, Sir.’ And General Key said,

461.text:
‘Yes, Sir. It’s an order!’ And he said,
‘No, Sir! I cannot go.’ And General Key

466.text:
said, ‘Toosey, it’s an order. You will
go to India, and furthermore you will leave

468.text:
tonight.’ And Toosey said, ‘Sir, in the
Territorial Army an order is a matter for

474.text: discussion. I cannot leave my men.’

477.text:
And afterwards he went on record to say it
was actually a very ill-thought-out order,

481.text:
because how would the men have looked at him,
the commanding officer, if he had fled and

486.text:
they had been left to be taken into captivity.
And two days later Singapore fell, and the

491.text:
greatest defeat in British military history
was suffered. And he, along with nearly 40,000

497.text:
British and Australian troops were taken prisoner
by the Japanese. And it was indeed a very

502.text: great humiliation and he felt it.

505.text:
But about three weeks into his captivity he
wrote the only letter that his wife was to

509.text:
receive from Singapore, and he said to her,
‘I have realised that there is a great job

515.text:
to be done here. These men need me to look
after them and that is what I am going to do.

519.text:
It is my duty.’ And it was this word
‘duty’ that was so important to him, and

525.text:
it was what functioned and what made him function
for the whole of the rest of his time in captivity.

530.text:
Now, initially they were kept on Singapore.
Eventually in the summer of 1942 the Japanese

538.text:
removed all the senior officers and left just
those of the rank of lieutenant-colonel and

543.text:
below on Singapore island. And about three
months later they decided they were going

547.text:
to be able to use this enormous force of men
as slave labour. And they decided they were

554.text: going to use the men to build a railway.

557.text:
Now the railway was going to run from Thailand
to Burma, and the reason for the railway was

562.text:
an overland route because the shipping in
the Gulf of Siam was being severely bombed

568.text:
by the Americans, and the Japanese were desperate
to get their munitions and men and provisions

574.text:
up to the western border for their invasion
of India.

579.text:
Now many people have assumed that the Thailand-Burma
railway was a spur of the moment decision

582.text:
by the Japanese. That is disrespecting the
Japanese. They were hugely organised, and

589.text:
they were in fact already surveying the route
of the railway in 1937 when this photograph

595.text:
was taken, and they were using drawings drawn
up by German engineers.

600.text:
The British had considered the possibility
of building a railway from Bangkok, in effect,

606.text:
or Nong Pladuk - where the railway starts
in Thailand - up to Burma, at the end of the

610.text:
19th century, but had come to the conclusion
that the jungle conditions, where diseases

615.text:
such as cholera and dysentery and beriberi
are rife, were so bad that the conditions

622.text:
for the men working on such a project would
be too... there would be too high a loss of life.

627.text:
But the Japanese had no such problem at this
stage, they had by then 60,000 men available

633.text:
for a workforce, and in addition about 250,000
men from Burma, from Malaya, who they could

641.text:
use to swell the workforce and to work on
the railway. So, that was the plan. They would

647.text:
build it from Nong Pladuk on the one end and
from Thanbyuzayat in Burma on the other, and

652.text:
the two railways would meet at a place called
Kon Kuta, which I don’t know if you can

657.text:
see, but it’s right in the middle of the screen, and is 
absolutely hard up on the Thailand-Burma border.

662.text:
Now, Toosey was told in October that he was
going to be sent up to Thailand and his men

668.text:
were going to be in a much better environment
than on Singapore, there would be more food,

675.text:
They were squeezed, 35 men, 30-35 men, into
these rice trucks. Now, rice trucks are fine

684.text:
for transporting Japanese troops because the
average height of a Japanese soldier is about

688.text:
5ft 4in, but for the British Army, and for
the Australian Army in particular, it was

693.text:
purgatory because these men, average height
5ft 8in, 5ft 10in, they were bent double

698.text:
in the trucks, and in fact there’s a rather
wonderful drawing by Jack Chalker, who was

704.text:
an artist who was up on the railway in his
early twenties, and he drew this drawing of

709.text:
men huddled up in the trucks, squeezed in with all 
their baggage and everything on top of them.

714.text:
It was a horrible journey, Toosey said. It
lasted for three days and four nights and

719.text:
in that time many of the men who were in his
truck had dysentery. It was extremely uncomfortable

724.text:
in the sweltering heat of the daytime, and
the freezing bitter cold of the night-time.

729.text:
So, by the time they got up to Nong Pladuk,
or rather to Ban Pong in Thailand,

735.text: they were in a pretty poor shape.

738.text:
They had one night in a transit camp and then
they were bussed. Some of very few who were

742.text:
actually sent by transport, most were made
to walk, but they were bussed in a series

746.text:
of lorries up to a place called Tamarkan,
which I will show you a map of in a second.

751.text:
And they arrived at this camp and it was,
at the time, being run by a Major Roberts

756.text:
from the Anti-Tank Regiment. And it was a
very small camp. It had only about space for

761.text:
250, but Toosey with 650 men was going to
triple the size of the camp, so the Thais

768.text:
were ordered by the Japanese to supply building
materials and the men had to build their own

772.text:
huts. And as you can see there are two men
here building a hut at Tamarkan.

777.text:
The huts were built entirely out of bamboo,
not a nail was used in the construction, and

782.text:
they were large bamboo poles, about one and
a half times the size of an old-fashioned

786.text:
telegraph pole. And the huts were covered
in attap roof - attap is a palm - and they

791.text:
were layered on just like large roof tiles.
And Toosey said when the huts were well kept-up,

797.text:
when there was time to look after the roof,
basically they were dry. But an awful lot

803.text:
of bugs fell out of the roof, and those men
who hated spiders and any other critters had

808.text: a very unpleasant time sleeping in those huts.

811.text:
They were about 300ft long, so 100 metres,
and each man had a bamboo... a space on a

818.text:
bamboo platform that was about 6ft long and
about 20in wide, so fine for them to lie and

825.text:
sleep on, but not enough room for them to turn over 
so they didn’t disturb the man next to them.

832.text:
Now the camp at Tamarkan was, as far as Toosey
was concerned, in a very good spot. It was

838.text:
close to a river, and as you can see in the
bottom right-hand corner there’s a little

842.text:
sign that says POW camp. This river was the
river Mae Klong. It was an enormous river

847.text:
that met up at the town Kanchanaburi where
Tamarkan was - Tamarkan’s a little sort

853.text:
of village about three miles outside of Kanchanaburi
- and the two rivers met. The Mae Klong met

860.text:
the river Kwai Noi, and it’s the river Kwai...
the word ‘Kwai’ that stuck in the prisoners’ minds.

867.text:
And Toosey was told when he arrived at this
camp that his job was to build two bridges

871.text:
over the river. The first would be a temporary
wooden bridge that would be built in the space

876.text:
of three months, and then there would be a
concrete and steel bridge which would take

882.text:
about six months to build. And the reason
that the Japanese needed a steel and concrete

887.text:
bridge over this river was because during
the monsoon season it swelled from about 20

892.text:
metres to something in the region of 200 metres,
and the Japanese realised that it was a major

897.text:
engineering obstacle and it would require
a serious structure.

901.text:
So, Toosey’s job was quite simply to build
these two bridges. He had, by the time they

907.text:
started work on the bridges, 2,500 men at
Tamarkan and he was completely in charge.

914.text:
He told the Japanese that he would agree to
work, and the reason that he would agree was

918.text:
because this had already been preordained
by General Percival in Singapore.

924.text:
Now, it’s very important to know that, because in the
film the row between Colonel Saito and Colonel

932.text:
Nicholson is whether or not British officers or British 
men should be working for the Japanese war effort.

937.text:
But Percival had already agreed with Yamashita,
and he was in no negotiating position, that

942.text:
the Japanese could use the British and the
Australian men, the Allied men if you like,

947.text:
as the labour force. He didn’t like having
to do that, but that was the condition. What,

951.text:
of course, he didn’t know was that the Japanese
were going to use the men to build this railway.

958.text:
And this railway was a massive construction.
It was 415km long and along its route were

964.text:
688 bridges, of which only nine were constructed
out of steel or concrete - eight in Burma

970.text:
and the one in Thailand. And this is a typical
bridge. It is not the house-of-cards bridge

976.text:
which fell down four times during its construction, but 
it is one of the bridges along the route of the Kwai Noi.

982.text:
In fact, interestingly, the river actually
never crosses the river Kwai Noi, it runs

987.text:
alongside it, but the reason for the bridges
was all the little tiny culverts and gulleys

992.text: that swelled of course in the monsoon season.

996.text:
Now when Pierre Boulle and co came along to
write the story of the Bridge on the River

1000.text:
Kwai, they had a bridge in mind but of course
nothing physical. And when Sam Spiegel who

1007.text:
directed and... sorry, who produced the film
'The Bridge on the River Kwai' came to look

1011.text:
at the possibilities, he sent his art director
out to Thailand and the art director said,

1016.text:
‘This is a hopeless place to build a bridge.
The land is flat and there’s one there anyway.

1020.text:
We need something more dramatic.’ So, he
went to Sri Lanka, where his wife came from,

1025.text:
and he found the most beautiful site at a
place called Kitulgala about three hours outside

1029.text:
Colombo. And there he decided they would construct
the film bridge. But what was this bridge to look like?

1035.text:
Well, Sam Spiegel, who was a very flamboyant
character as I’m sure many of you know,

1040.text:
put a competition out for students and he
announced that he wished a design for a bridge

1045.text:
to be made and this would be used in the film
'Bridge on the River Kwai'.

1048.text:
And these two students from the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology sent this design in

1053.text:
- they had a reading week but they didn’t
do any reading - and this in fact was the

1056.text:
bridge that was used, the shape of the bridge
that was used for the film.

1061.text:
Now the crux of the film, as I’ve mentioned,
is the stormy relationship between Alec Guinness’s

1067.text:
character, Colonel Nicholson, and the Japanese
character, Colonel Saito. In fact, Toosey

1072.text:
was anything but confrontational. As an experienced
salesman in the bank he knew how to get the

1080.text:
very best out of people, and this photograph
of him here, OK he’s smiling because he’s

1084.text:
just won a major award, but it’s a very
typical photograph of him. He was charismatic,

1089.text:
he was quite loud, he was very generous-spirited,
and above all he strongly believed that his

1096.text:
men were the most important thing in his life
and that his leadership was dependent upon

1104.text:
And when he first saw the film and he saw
the ridiculous stormy row between Saito and

1112.text:
Nicholson he turned round to his daughter
and he said, ‘That was never like that.

1116.text:
You could never have confronted the Japanese
and caused them to lose face. That would have

1120.text:
been fatal, I would not have survived.’
But, of course, for the drama of the film

1124.text:
it works very well. And at this moment in
time Saito has just announced to Nicholson

1130.text:
that he is going to order not only men but
British officers to work, and Nicholson refuses,

1135.text:
cites the Geneva Conventions, Saito snatches
the Geneva Conventions out of Nicholson’s

1140.text:
hand and slaps him across the face. It’s
an extremely dramatic moment. Oh yes, and

1145.text:
he then orders Nicholson to be locked up in
that metal hut you can see in the background.

1151.text:
And in one of the most dramatic scenes in
the film, Nicholson, after three and a half

1155.text:
weeks, is dragged almost dead out of this
hut and into Saito’s office. And it’s

1161.text:
at that moment that the film changes completely
and Saito has to admit to Nicholson that his

1168.text:
bridge is not being built successfully because
the British officers and the British men are

1172.text:
not listening to the Japanese instructions
and that is where Nicholson says, ‘Allow

1177.text:
me to take over. My engineers will build you
a better bridge in a different place and to

1181.text:
Tokyo’s timetable.’ And that is what the
Japanese object to so much about the film

1186.text:
'Bridge on the River Kwai', the implication
that they are incapable engineers.

1190.text:
But the story of Nicholson’s holing-up was
actually based on a true story which Pierre

1196.text:
Boulle will have heard and which, when the
film was rewritten by David Lean who took

1202.text:
the script and Boulle’s novel, he took this
story, and this is of a man called Captain

1207.text:
William Mortimer Drower. He was an Oxford-educated
translator. He spoke fluent Japanese, but

1214.text:
of course honorific Japanese as opposed to
peasant Japanese which is what the guards

1219.text:
and particularly the Korean lads at the camps
would have spoken.

1223.text:
And Bill Drower had the dubious honour of
having started at the Burma end of the railway

1228.text:
and ended up right down beyond Tamarkan at
an officers-only camp in Kanchanaburi in 1945.

1235.text:
And it was there where he was working as Toosey’s
translator that he fell out with the Japanese commander.

1242.text:
The Japanese commander had been hugely insulted
by Drower implying... implying to one of his

1249.text:
guards that the war would soon be over and
the Japanese would be held accountable for

1253.text:
the atrocities that had taken place during
the construction of the railway.

1258.text:
Drower was ordered into Noguchi’s office.
Noguchi threw a major wobbly at him. He belted

1265.text:
Drower round the head, broke Drower’s arm
and in the process of the fight Drower fell

1270.text:
onto the commander’s table and the table
was broken and of course the Emperor had been

1276.text:
insulted and Drower was condemned to 76...
no, in fact he was condemned to life underground,

1283.text: which lasted for 76 days and nights.

1285.text:
And this is a photograph of the ghastly hovel
that Bill Drower was forced to live in, imprisoned.

1293.text:
He received only a rice ball daily from the
Japanese, but an immensely brave man called

1301.text:
Peter Fane was determined to do something
for Drower. So he, who was the young officer

1306.text:
who took Drower his rice ball on a daily basis,
put vitamins which he’d been given by the

1311.text:
doctors into the rice ball and the doctors were 
sure that that would help to save Drower’s life.

1316.text: We’ll come back to him later.

1319.text:
So, the two bridges at Tamarkan were constructed.
They were constructed by the Japanese Railway

1325.text:
Engineering Unit with the British and Australian
and Dutch, who were also at Tamarkan, soldiers

1331.text:
simply providing the labour. And as you see,
there is a Japanese soldier up on the wooden

1336.text:
bridge. The British and the Australians and
the Dutch were simply slaves. They moved earth,

1342.text:
they moved sleepers, they moved rails, they
didn’t do anything technical. And certainly

1348.text:
when it came to the construction of the metal-and-concrete
bridge at Tamarkan. You can see in the foreground

1354.text:
the Australian officer... guard and his lad
in his slouch hat, but all the Japanese officers

1361.text:
working on the railway bridge, it was they
who oversaw the construction of the railway,

1365.text:
and again this is why they feel so furious
that they were insulted in the film.

1371.text:
Now, in the film of course Alec Guinness take[s]...
or Colonel Nicholson takes tremendous pride

1376.text:
in this beautiful bridge which has been film[ed]...
which has been constructed by his men in a

1381.text:
better place and into a quicker time than
the Japanese ever could have made it. And

1387.text:
all along there is the plan in the film for
the bridge to be blown up when it is first

1393.text:
used, and it allowed the character of William
Holden, who’s in the middle, to be introduced.

1400.text:
This is not in the book 'Bridge on the River
Kwai', it is introduced, the American character’s

1405.text:
introduced by Sam Spiegel because he wanted
to have an American love story in the film.

1410.text:
So, there he is planning the destruction of
the bridge.

1413.text:
Now, the destruction of the bridge in the
film was the most spectacular explosion in

1419.text:
movie history. It was the first really expensive
movie explosion and Sam Spiegel was rightly

1425.text:
proud of it. He told everybody who would listen
that it had cost $250,000. I found the accounts

1430.text:
for the film, it was $53,000 dollars, but
why spoil a good story.

1432.text:
Now, the story of the blowing up of the bridge,
if you’ll just permit me a quick diversion,

1437.text:
was actually a very funny one because Don
Ashton, who was the director of...the artistic

1442.text:
director, had set up six cameras around...
and they had to do it for real - there were

1446.text:
no special effects in those days - they had
to do it for real. And he’d set up six cameras

1451.text:
– one on the train and five around the bridge
– and he’d given David Lean, the director,

1455.text:
a wooden panel with six light bulbs on it.
And what every cameraman was told to do was

1461.text:
to set his camera running, press the switch
which meant that he’d jump clear out of

1465.text: his pit and get the hell out of the way.

1469.text:
Come the day, Sam Spiegel, the great producer,
had invited all the dignitaries to Kitulgala.

1475.text:
There was a champagne reception, there were
balconies built so that they could watch this

1478.text:
spectacular explosion - about 1,000 people
turned up, I believe. The moment came, ‘toot-toot’

1484.text:
went the train, the first light came on, the
cameraman who had been in the train had jumped

1490.text:
clear, the second light, the third light,
the fourth light, the fifth light, the sixth

1492.text:
light did not light up. And David Lean had
to make a split-second decision. Did he risk

1498.text:
the life of Freddy Ford, the cameraman, or
did he stay his hand? And he stayed his hand

1504.text:
and the train ran over the bridge and ploughed
into the sandbags on the other side.

1511.text:
Two days later, in front of a small number
of people from Kitulgala, this tremendous

1518.text:
explosion happened. So, next time you watch
the film you can think about that, but it

1522.text:
really is one of the most spectacular explosions
in history.

1525.text:
Now the bridge on the river Kwai itself, the
bridge at Tamarkan, was also destroyed, but

1530.text:
it wasn’t destroyed by mines, it was destroyed
from the air, and it was destroyed by the

1535.text:
Royal Air Force in June 1945. So, the construction
of the bridge had been completed by 1 May

1543.text:
’43. The bridge was used successfully by
the Japanese for two and a half years, or

1548.text:
two and a quarter years. Initially the railway
was used to take munitions, and men, and provisions

1554.text:
up to the Burma border, and then latterly
of course to retreat back.

1561.text:
What’s interesting about this photograph
is that the steel-and-concrete bridge has

1566.text:
been put finally completely out of use, but
the wooden bridge is still there. And it was

1572.text:
bombed to destruction nine times, and nine
times it was reconstructed. And in fact that

1576.text:
was the bridge that the Japanese went on using
till the end of the war.

1581.text:
So the bridge at Tamarkan was finished by
1 May 1945. Toosey had had the very good fortune,

1589.text:
he would always say, of being at a camp where
there was fresh water. There was never cholera

1594.text:
at Tamarkan. There was disease. His men were
underfed like all prisoners of the Japanese,

1600.text:
they were overworked like all prisoners of
the Japanese and they lived in pretty squalid

1605.text:
conditions. But Toosey was a man who believed enormously 
that dignity and morale was of paramount importance.

1613.text:
He also, on the advice of the doctors, insisted
on cleanliness in his camp and there were

1618.text:
to be no beards at Tamarkan. He also interestingly
introduced a no-officers'-mess regime, which

1626.text:
today doesn’t sound extraordinary but in
1942 was practically heretical. But he said

1632.text:
unashamedly, ‘We only have a very limited
amount of food. Why should the officers eat

1638.text:
more than the men? And indeed why should the
officers sleep in officers’ sleeping quarters?

1643.text:
They too will sleep with the men in their
huts.’ And in those enormous huts 300 yards

1649.text:
long... 300ft long, the officers would sleep
at the doors so that they could warn the men

1654.text:
if any Korean guard or Japanese guard was
coming into the hut if the men were, for example,

1660.text:
drawing or writing diaries, which was completely
illegal.

1663.text:
So Toosey had set up really quite a strict
regime at Tamarkan, but he also negotiated

1669.text:
hard with the Japanese. He’d insisted that
they had one rest day, not a week but about

1675.text:
every ten days. He had also persuaded the
chap in charge, who happened to be called

1682.text:
Regimental Sergeant Major Saito, that he needed
better food for his men. Slightly controversially

1686.text:
he said, ‘If I have better food, fewer men
will go sick and therefore you will have more

1691.text:
workforce.’ That was construed by some as
collaboration. As far as he was concerned

1696.text:
it was just plain good sense, he needed these
men to get back safely.

1700.text:
He also negotiated the use of a canteen at
Tamarkan. And that was enormously valuable,

1705.text:
because at the canteen the officers who earned
a little bit of money and the men who earned

1709.text:
a pittance could spend money on duck eggs,
on cigarettes, on perhaps peanut cookies that

1714.text:
they would have an opportunity to make in
the kitchens and that would supplement their

1718.text:
diet. But it was also a very useful source
of money for him, Toosey. In addition to taxing

1724.text:
the officers 30 and later 60 per cent, he
had a fund that he could use whenever he could

1729.text: get out to buy materials for the hospitals.

1732.text:
And in fact although the rate of death on
the railway was 27 per cent, in his camp about

1739.text:
of the 2,500 who were building the bridges
at Tamarkan only eleven men died, and most

1744.text:
of those died of diseases that they might
well have died of anyway.

1748.text:
So the railway was continuing to be built
at the end of April ’43, and Toosey asked

1754.text:
to be sent with his men further up the railway.
He was refused. He was very upset about this,

1759.text:
but he was told by the Japanese that he was
to set up a hospital at Tamarkan because despite

1766.text:
the very cruel attitude that the Japanese
had to the sick, they realised that the schedule

1771.text:
for their completion of the railway was being
held up by the fact that so many of the prisoners

1776.text:
were suffering from not only chronic, but
also acute conditions. And this beautiful

1781.text:
countryside in Thailand, if any of you have
visited it will know it’s one of the most

1786.text:
lovely countries on earth, but the jungle
has hideous conditions endemic in it. Cholera

1792.text:
broke out in the spring of 1943 and that wiped
through not only the British and Australian

1798.text:
camps, but also through the camps of the native
workers and they died in their thousands.

1804.text:
83,000 of them died during the construction of the 
railway to our just over 12,000 Allied troops.

1811.text:
And the conditions up the railway were gruesome
beyond belief. The... this is a photograph

1817.text:
taken by a man called George Aspinal who very
bravely had smuggled a camera through Changi

1823.text:
and up on to the railway and it shows a cholera
camp, and they were lying not under bamboo

1828.text:
huts but under tents. And the cholera huts
were always a long way from the camp because

1833.text: it’s such a hideously infectious disease.

1836.text:
This is a drawing by the great artist Ronald
Searle who, as you know, has just recently

1840.text:
died. He was a survivor of the railway and
this is a drawing he made of a man who was

1845.text:
dying of the vitamin deficiency disease beriberi.
And this is a particularly gruesome drawing

1850.text:
of a dysentery hut by a Dutch artist by the
name of Jan Van Holthe who was with Toosey

1855.text:
both at Tamarkan and then later at another
camp called Nong Pladuk. The conditions these

1860.text:
men were living in, especially up further
in the jungle, were absolutely gruesome.

1864.text:
So, the Japanese ordered Toosey to set up
Tamarkan as a hospital. Now the word hospital

1871.text:
conjures the image of white sheets, clean
beds, silver trolleys rattling down corridors,

1876.text:
whereas in reality all Tamarkan was was a
compound for desperately sick men. And this

1881.text:
drawing by Jack Chalker is of men being unloaded
from the barges that had brought them down

1886.text: the railway and to Tamarkan camp.

1890.text:
Toosey had eventually nine doctors and 45
orderlies. When he was first given responsibility

1897.text:
for Tamarkan as a hospital - he wasn’t a
doctor himself - the Japanese gave him a large

1901.text:
bottle of iodine, three bandages and six packets
of aspirin. But he had the most fantastic

1908.text:
ally. This is a man called Doctor Arthur Moon,
he was a gynaecologist - ladies - from Sydney.

1915.text:
But he was a fantastic doctor. He was a surgeon.
He’d been with the now-world-famous Weary

1921.text:
Dunlop, Doctor Weary Dunlop, who was a surgeon
from Australia - although British-born, I

1927.text:
think - who was operating further up the railway.
And Toosey had the great good fortune of having

1932.text:
Doctor Moon as one of his staff and the senior
doctor.

1935.text:
Moon had the most wonderful bedside manner,
and even when he was giving patients the worst

1940.text:
possible news that they would lose a limb
– many limbs were lost as the result of

1944.text:
jungle ulcers – he had the ability to make
them feel that it was less dangerous than

1951.text:
But still the death rate at Tamarkan was horrendous,
because with so little medicine the men were

1956.text:
dying of entirely preventable diseases. And
they were dying at a rate of about six a day,

1962.text: most of whom were having to be buried by Toosey.

1965.text:
And then an extraordinary thing happened.
In July 1943, so just three months after the

1971.text:
camp had become a hospital, a Thai delegation
from the Red Cross arrived at Tamarkan to

1976.text:
inspect the camp and the translator, who was
an Anglo-born Thai-speaking sergeant in the

1984.text:
British Army, turned round to Toosey, caught
him on one side while they were visiting one

1989.text:
of the huts, and he said, ‘There is help
in Bangkok. I can provide a link to somebody

1994.text:
who has money and medicines, and this money
and medicine can be provided for your hospital

2000.text:
if you sign your number, rank and name on
this piece of paper.’

2003.text:
Now it was a huge risk, and this photograph
- which is appalling, I apologise - was taken

2010.text:
in October 1943 just at the height of the
scheme when they had decided, despite all

2017.text:
the risks, to go with Moon’s... with Toosey’s
suggestion and to get in touch with what was

2022.text:
called the V Organisation in Bangkok. And
this photograph was taken, there’s Toosey

2026.text:
sitting on the right, Doctor Arthur Moon standing
in the centre, Captain David Boyle sitting

2031.text: on the left, and there are three Korean guards.

2034.text:
Toosey said, ‘In those months when we were
receiving medicines from Bangkok and they

2039.text:
were smuggled in in baskets of fruit, you
cannot imagine how badly I slept. It was probably

2044.text:
the most dangerous and foolhardy thing we
ever did.‘ But, and even though only four

2049.text:
men knew about the smuggling of these drugs
and medicines, it had a huge impact on the

2054.text:
camp, and the death rate fell from six a day
to about three a week by October-November

2060.text:
’43. So, it was an extraordinary help to
them, and most of them didn’t know about

2065.text:
that help until 1948 when Toosey put out an
appeal for the man, Mr Boon Pong, who had

2071.text:
been the link man in Kanchanaburi and who had 
supplied the medicines and money to Tamarkan camp.

2078.text:
Now the railway was finished on 25 October
1943. It had taken less than 12 months to

2084.text:
build, and the Japanese then sent many of
the men who had been working on the railway

2089.text: to Japan to work in the mines.

2092.text:
Toosey was sent down to a big base camp called
Nong Pladuk, that was away from Kanchanaburi,

2098.text:
and there he was in charge of 8,000 men and
they were simply moving materials and loading

2103.text:
and unloading trains for the Japanese at the
marshalling yards. And he had a new problem.

2109.text:
There was slightly better food, there was
much less work – although they were still

2113.text:
worked very hard – the numbers of sick dropped
dramatically, and the men very often were

2118.text:
becoming bored, so he set up a concert party.
He had two concert parties in fact, a Dutch

2124.text:
concert party and the English concert party.
And as you can see from this rather wonderful

2129.text:
programme that he was given for one of the
concert parties, there was any number of entertainments

2134.text:
including, I must point out, 'Wizardus, Magic
and Mystery'.

2139.text:
This was a magician who was a bombardier.
He was in Toosey’s camp. He was a man who

2143.text:
Toosey admired enormously. I think it would
be fair to describe him as a loner. He always

2148.text:
said of his experiences in the camps, ‘I
knew I had to survive and I didn’t need

2153.text:
anybody else to help me survive.’ But he
was an enormously brave man this lad, Fergus

2158.text:
Ancorn. He was a member of the Magic Circle
already in the 1930s. He’s still alive today,

2164.text:
he’s still a member of the Magic Circle
and he reminds me he’s not, thank you very

2168.text: much, the oldest member of the Magic Circle.

2170.text:
But he was an example of the kind of man who
Toosey could rely on. And Toosey always said,

2175.text:
‘In those prison camps it didn’t matter
whether a man had rank or status. It didn’t

2180.text:
matter a button if he was a lord, what mattered
is if he was a man who was brave enough to

2184.text:
work with me. Those men, those men like Fergus
Ancorn were the salt of the earth because

2189.text:
they could help.' And how Fergus Ancorn helped
Toosey was to keep the men in the hospital

2195.text:
huts entertained. And that, to him, was so
valuable because those men, rather than lying

2200.text:
down and dying of despair, felt that somebody
was looking after their spiritual good health

2205.text: as well as their physical good health.

2208.text:
Toosey was at Nong Pladuk until the summer
of... the spring of 1945 and then he was moved

2214.text:
up to Kanchanaburi where he was with Bill
Drower, the translator, and there they were

2220.text:
in an officers-only camp for about five months,
six months. And then the war came to an end,

2227.text:
and this photograph taken by Major David Smiley,
a rather bashed-up photograph I’m afraid,

2232.text:
is of Ubon camp which was the camp where Toosey’s
men had all been sent to when Toosey was separated

2239.text:
from them at the beginning of ’45. And Toosey,
immediately the war was ended, was determined

2244.text:
to get back to his men, he wanted to be with
them as quickly as possible so that he could

2249.text:
celebrate the end of the war and look after
them on the journey home.

2253.text:
And this remarkable photograph is of the reunion.
And it’s Toosey taking the parade, here

2259.text:
are all the officers who have been returned,
and round the edge of the perimeter of the

2263.text:
parade ground are 3,500 men. I interviewed
David Smiley and he said, ‘You cannot imagine

2270.text:
how impressive it was to see those men dressed
in the ball bags and their ripped-up shorts.

2276.text:
They’d been prisoners for three and a half
years and they stood there and they saluted

2281.text:
as we sang ‘God Save the King’. And up
went the union flag and I wept.’

2287.text:
So Toosey’s reign in Thailand had been one
of keeping morale together, keeping the men

2296.text:
as healthy as he could, physically and mentally,
and keeping the Japanese at bay. And one of

2302.text:
his prisoners, in fact the man who drew that
ghastly picture of the men in the dysentery

2307.text:
hut, drew this drawing for him which was a
picture of him kicking a Korean guard up the

2312.text:
backside and having above him the union flag
and the Dutch flag. And the Dutch were hugely

2319.text:
proud to thank him for the contribution he’d
made to their experiences in the prison camps.

2325.text:
He came back to Britain in 1945, November,
they came back by ship, and he was frankly

2332.text:
deeply traumatised. He arrived home, two of
his three children didn’t recognise him.

2337.text:
My mother Gillian screamed when he tried to
embrace her because she hadn’t been touched

2341.text:
by a man since the beginning of the war, and
his wife was deposed. She found his return

2347.text:
enormously difficult because he had returned
a hero, there was no doubt about it, those

2351.text:
men who had been in his prison camps held
him in very high esteem, and she regarded

2355.text:
him quite simply as the stupidest man she’d
ever met in her life.

2359.text:
But he was... he was a man traumatised. This
photograph was taken in 1946, he’s back

2364.text:
in his office at Barings Bank, completely
unable to get his head around the changes

2370.text:
that had taken place in the six and a half
years since he’d left home, and the three

2374.text:
and a half years since he’d been in captivity
of the Japanese.

2378.text:
Barings Bank to their eternal credit - pre-Nick
Leeson - took him in hand and they knew that

2385.text:
they had the... one of the great heroes of
the captivity period working for them, but

2392.text:
also a man who was completely broken up and
discombobulated. So they sent him to South

2398.text:
America, initially for six weeks, but eventually
for six months. And he had the wonderful experience

2404.text:
of travelling all around South America as
an ambassador for Barings Bank, trying to

2408.text:
drum up business, but being away – away
from Britain, away from Thailand. And he wrote

2413.text:
a wonderful letter to his boss at Barings,
Evelyn Baring, in August, just before he came

2418.text:
home, saying, ‘I went with my friend Dum
Tweedie up into the north of Peru and I saw

2425.text:
a native hut, and I saw women sitting in the
native hut cooking and I thought to myself

2430.text:
this reminds me of my experience in Thailand
except now I wasn’t envious of them.’

2437.text:
He very quickly readjusted when he got back,
and in 1947 he set up the Far Eastern Prisoners

2444.text:
of War Federation – this was a group of
associations and clubs all over Great Britain

2448.text:
where FEPOWs – Far Eastern Prisoners of
War – could go and have meets and talks

2454.text:
and events and so forth, and annually there
was a big get-together.

2458.text:
Initially Toosey, who’s standing here in
the background with a pipe, initially he was

2462.text:
the vice president. He insisted that General
Percival should be appointed the president,

2467.text:
which was quite controversial because Percival
had, in effect, been responsible for their

2471.text:
captivity. But the men were very proud of
Percival’s ten years that he spent looking

2476.text:
after the Far Eastern Prisoners of War – in
fact 20 years, he died in 1966 - and Toosey

2481.text:
always said that he thought it gave Percival
a new lease of life after the humiliation of the war.

2487.text:
The reason I show this photograph is because
Toosey was not only dealing with the men and

2491.text:
keeping up his duty towards them on the grand
scale if you like, on the large scale, but

2496.text:
he was also doing it on a personal level.
And the man standing behind my mother in his

2500.text:
suit is a man called Arthur Osborne who was
Toosey’s batman for the second half of his

2505.text:
captivity. And Osborne came back to Britain
with chronic malaria, very severe mental problems

2511.text:
and he kept writing to Toosey and asking if
he could come and live with him. This lad

2514.text:
was 22 when they came home after the war.
And Toosey obviously had no use as a middle-class

2520.text:
banker for a valet, so he found Osborne a
job on a ship, and Osborne worked as a ship’s

2526.text:
purser, gradually going up the ranks. And
he worked for 17 years travelling all over

2532.text:
And eventually he came back to Britain, and
he came to see Toosey and he gave Toosey a

2538.text:
photograph of the bridge at Tamarkan just
after it was finished construction. And he

2543.text:
gave that to Toosey as a memory of the great
time they had spent together. And Toosey in

2549.text:
turn gave him the one thing that really meant
something to him, he gave him one of his labrador

2555.text:
puppies. But he also gave Osborne the only
interview he ever gave about his experiences

2562.text:
So how do I know all this? Because, of course,
like all other prisoners of war, he never

2566.text:
spoke of his experiences on the Thailand-Burma
railway, and with respect most certainly not

2571.text: to little girls, and I was 16 when he died.

2573.text:
Well, he fortunately was encouraged by his
older son, Patrick, just before he died, to

2579.text:
make a series of tape recordings. And he spoke
for 30 hours over a period of 18 months, about

2584.text:
half an hour or an hour a week, to a professor
of history from Liverpool University. And

2590.text:
to my great delight, a set of these tape recordings
not only existed at the Imperial War Museum,

2594.text:
and they still do, but a set had also been
made for the family. So I was able to spend

2599.text:
wonderful hours driving, cooking in the kitchen
for my children, listening to these tapes,

2604.text:
hearing his voice again. This photograph was
taken of him in 1974 after major heart surgery,

2610.text:
and my memory of him is of a very old and
very frail man, but a very lovely and kind man.

2616.text:
But in the tapes his voice is strong and he
laughs and he jokes, and when he tells a story

2622.text:
of something that is very gruesome you can
feel him, his voice changes and he almost

2628.text:
disappears from the room mentally and he’s
back there in Thailand. And they’re a very,

2633.text: very powerful record of his time on the railway.

2637.text:
So the film came out, seven Oscars, eight
Oscars, I can’t remember the exact number,

2641.text:
hugely – seven, it says so there – seven
Oscars, hugely successful film, and Toosey

2647.text:
just went to see it with his daughter and
didn't really think very much more about it.

2651.text:
But the prisoners of war were furious because
they saw it as a terrible slur on his leadership

2656.text:
and they wanted to him to object. But there
was nobody to object to – people believed

2661.text: the Hollywood story was the true story.

2665.text:
When I was doing research for the book, I
decided I had not only to go out to Thailand

2669.text:
and see the real bridge, but I had to go and
see where Pierre Boulle and the film crew

2674.text:
had put the bridge on the river Kwai. And
here it is at Kitulgala, and the footings

2679.text:
are the only thing... the concrete footings
are the only things that are left of the film

2685.text:
bridge that was blown up so successfully second
time round in 1957.

2689.text:
The real bridge, this is a copy of a photograph
that Osborne gave to Toosey in the 1950s,

2695.text:
the real bridge was repaired by the Thais
and is still used today. And the railway runs

2701.text:
from Bangkok up to a place called Nam Tok
and it takes schoolchildren from Kanchanaburi

2708.text:
And today the bridge on the river Kwai is
an enormous tourist attraction. And I have

2713.text:
to say it was the one moment when my mother
slightly faltered when we went to the bridge

2718.text:
at sunset and there was an enormous crowd
of Japanese, and she said, ‘I just had to

2723.text:
pinch myself, darling. I did find that slightly
traumatic.’

2728.text:
Let me end, because I’m on time, with the...
very quickly, the story of Bill Drower.

2733.text:
Bill Drower was hauled out of his underground
prison on 17 August 1945 and he was sent to

2740.text:
a hospital at Nakompatong. And this is where
a photograph was taken after which this drawing

2746.text:
was made. He was barely alive, he was suffering
from blackwater fever, he’d been delirious,

2751.text:
a rat had eaten into his foot. He was in the
most appalling, appalling state. But Bill

2757.text:
Drower survived, he became a diplomat, he
spoke fluent Japanese still – here he is

2764.text:
on the right with Toosey’s son Patrick looking
very like his father. And in 1994 Bill Drower

2771.text:
went on a reconciliation mission to Japan,
and he was taken as an honoured guest all

2777.text:
around Japan. ‘The condition,’ he said,
‘of my coming is that I’m allowed to give

2781.text: a speech in Japanese, and I will use the honorific.’

2785.text:
He gave a speech in Tokyo. He was then taken
to Osaka and Fukuoka and Hiroshima, and on

2791.text:
the train going from Osaka to Fukuoka on the
bullet train he sat back and he said to his

2797.text:
young translator, ‘This is a very comfortable
train, I’m very impressed by Japanese engineering.’

2803.text:
And the Japanese - I’m not going to insult
him by doing the accent - the Japanese translator

2808.text:
turned round to Bill and he said, ‘It’s
a very good... yes, it’s a very good one.

2812.text:
It’s built by one of our most famous engineers.
He built a railway during the Second World

2816.text:
War.’ And Bill said, ‘I know, I helped
him.’

2821.text:
So, ladies and gentlemen, I’m going to end
with the good news story that Bill Drower

2826.text:
did survive, despite his appalling times on
the railway. And he and many of the others

2831.text:
would tell you that despite many of the horrible
things that happened to them it was, for them,

2835.text:
a university of life. And for some of them...
for some of them a great experience.

2841.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much
indeed.
